item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning of the Tone Arm Carriage Position Switches and a Non-Returning Carriage
item.description:

Instead, it would travel to the center of the platter and stop. item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Reservoir and Motor Capacitors Using a 3D Printed Adapter
item.description:
I’m working on restoring a Beogram 4000 turntable, and one of the challenges is finding modern replacements for the large capacitors used in the 1970s. I received a 3D-printed adapter that allows me to neatly install smaller, current-generation capacitors. item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the AC Motor Voltage
item.description:
During my Beogram 4000 turntable restoration, I observed a noisy motor, especially at 45 RPM. Replacing the electrolytic capacitors helped but didn’t solve the problem completely. To investigate further, I examined the motor voltage and the signal waveform from the Wien bridge oscillator, a clever design that uses an incandescent light bulb as a variable resistor for amplitude control. item.title: Beogram 4000: Polishing the Hood
item.description:
As a final step in restoring a Beogram 4000 turntable, the author polished its dust cover. This is a multi-step process that can take several hours, especially since this cover had significant damage. The author began by protecting the Bang & Olufsen logo with layers of insulation tape to prevent accidental sanding. They then used 220-grit sandpaper to smooth out the deep scratches, leaving a surface that resembled wood. To restore the shine, they progressed through approximately ten grades of sandpaper and micro-mesh polishing cloths, finishing with a polishing liquid...

item.title: Beogram 4000: Recapping the PCBs
item.description:
During my Beogram 4000 restoration, I replaced all electrolytic capacitors as a preventative measure, opting for durable 105C types from reputable Japanese brands. Tantalum capacitors, particularly in older equipment, can fail dramatically, even catching fire. On the power supply board, I discovered a missing screw and a loose one, potentially creating a dangerous short circuit scenario. Thankfully, no damage was evident. item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Solenoid and the Switches
item.description:
The Beogram 4000 restoration I’m working on requires some final adjustments. A key part of any complete restoration is calibrating the solenoid and its associated switches. This solenoid is critical as it manages the tonearm’s up/down movement and activates three important switches: audio muting, solenoid power control, and carriage transport. item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Light Bulbs in the Control Panel with LEDs
item.description:
Following the replacement of the reservoir and motor capacitors in the Beogram 4000, I focused on upgrading the control panel’s light bulbs. LEDs offer greater long-term stability and are generally preferable replacements for incandescent bulbs, except in cases where the original circuitry or aesthetics demand otherwise. Given that the control panel’s lighting is internal and not directly visible, LEDs are a suitable replacement.
